First evidence of podocin mutations in sporadic steroid-resistant nephrotic syndrome.
Mutations interact with nephrin to produce either nephrotic syndrome or focal glomerosclerosis, depending on alleles.
Ten NPHS2 autosomal recessive mutations have been identified in corticosteroid resistant familial nephrotic syndrome. Podocin plays a major role in glomerular filtration and podocyte physiology.

Mutations of NPHS1 or NPHS2, the genes encoding for nephrin and podocin, lead to early onset of heavy proteinuria, and rapid progression to end-stage renal disease, suggesting that both proteins are essential for the integrity of the glomerular filter.

In steroid-resistant nephrotic syndrome some missense mutations in NPHS2 lead to misfolding and mislocalization of mutated podocin and interfere with slit diaphragm structure and function by altering proper trafficking of nephrin to plasma membrane.

More than 15% of the p.R229Q association identified in patients are benign. [review]

Results found that in addition to mutations in COL4A5 type IV collagen gene, nephrin and podocin polymorphisms aggravated kidney damage, leading to focal segmental glomerulosclerosis (FSGS) with ruptures of the basement membrane and early renal failure. This study suggests a synergistic role for genes encoding basement membrane and slit diaphragm proteins as a cause of kidney injury due to FSGS.

The V260E variant is a good predictor of autosomal recessive SRNS in black South African children and could provide useful information in a clinical setting.

name: NPHS2 stomatin family member, podocin

pid.name: Nephrin/Neph1 signaling in the kidney podocyte

summary: This gene encodes a protein that plays a role in the regulation of glomerular permeability. Mutations in this gene cause steroid-resistant nephrotic syndrome. Alternative splicing results in multiple transcript variants. [provided by RefSeq, Jul 2014].
